content.rendered:
There are several things that I was not fortunate to learn as a child, and one of them was the meaning of the two letter word: “No.” And, admittedly, I’m still learning. But I’ve learned over the years how important this little word is to all aspects of life.

I think that I first leaned the meaning of “no” after when after the death of my wife (we were married an entire seven weeks before she died of cancer). Her stream of income ended, while the bills continued to roll in. Then the creditors began to write, and they weren’t love letters. It’s strange what super powers that tragedy will give you and, for me, the ability to say no was mine.

The ability to say no, not only to other but to ourselves, is a powerful tool in the life of an entrepreneur. That is because saying “no” to even the good things frees us up say “yes” to the best things. But it’s not an easy choice to make, and I had to learn the hard way.

It’a a lesson that I’m still learning to put into practice: at lest saying “no” to myself, especially to myself. But I’m working on it. I could blame the ease of credit cards, or marketing and advertising that seems to fill nearly every moment of our waking lives. Yet, I’m the one who must ultimately has to take responsibility of my choices, and no one else.

Yes, it’s hard lesson to learn, but it’s really never to late. And it’s never too late to change, as long as you believe that you can.
